Anniversary Edition) |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |date=June 20, 2007 |url=http://www.afi.com/100Years/movies10.aspx |accessdate=February 27, 2013}}</ref> Film directors ranked it 322nd in the 2012 edition of the decennial ''[[Sight & Sound]]'' poll,<ref name="sight and sound">{{cite web |title=The Greatest Films Poll: Gone with the Wind |year=2012 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |url=http://explore.bfi.org.uk/sightandsoundpolls/2012/film/4ce2b6ab5808b |accessdate=March 3, 2013}}</ref> and in 2016 it was selected as the ninth best "directorial achievement" in a [[Directors Guild of America]] members poll.<ref>{{cite web |title=The 80 Best-Directed Films |date=Spring 2016 |publisher=[[Directors Guild of America]] |url=http://www.dga.org/Craft/DGAQ/All-Articles/1602-Spring-2016/80th-Film-Poll.aspx |accessdate=May 4, 2016}}</ref> In 2014, it placed fifteenth in an extensive poll undertaken by ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', which ballotted every studio, agency, publicity firm and production house in the [[Hollywood]] region.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hollywood's 100 Favorite Films |date=June 25, 2014 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/best-hollywood-movies-all-time-818512 |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> ''Gone with the Wind'' was selected for preservation in the U.S. [[National Film Registry]] in 1989.<ref name="tcm articles" />
==Analysis==
===Racial criticism=== ''Gone with the Wind'' has been criticized as having perpetuated Civil War myths and black stereotypes.<ref name="Hernan">{{cite book |first1=Hernán |last1=Vera |first2=Andrew Mark |last2=Gordon |year=2003 |title=Screen Saviors: Hollywood Fictions of Whiteness |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]] |isbn=978-0-8476-9947-6 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=6ZAPD2YdBXYC&pg=PR8 viii] & [https://books.google.com/books?id=6ZAPD2YdBXYC&pg=PA102 102]}}</ref> [[David Reynolds (English historian)|David Reynolds]] writes that "The white women are elegant, their menfolk noble or at least dashing. And, in the background, the black slaves are mostly dutiful and content, clearly incapable of an independent existence." Reynolds likened ''Gone with the Wind'' to ''The Birth of a Nation'' and other re-imaginings of the South during the era of segregation, in which white Southerners are portrayed as defending traditional values and the issue of slavery is largely ignored.<ref name="Reynolds" /> The film has been described as a "regression" that promotes the myth of the black rapist and the honourable and defensive role of the [[Ku Klux Klan]] during Reconstruction,<ref name="Silk">{{cite book |first1=Catherine |last1=Silk |first2=Johnk |last2=Silk |year=1990 |title=Racism and Anti-Racism in American Popular Culture: Portrayals of African-Americans in Fiction and Film |publisher=[[Manchester University Press]] |isbn=978-0-7190-3070-3 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=JtNRAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA141 141]}}</ref> and as a "social propaganda" film offering a "[[white supremacist]]" view of the past.<ref name="Hernan" /> From 1972 to 1996, the [[Atlanta Historical Society]] held a number of ''Gone with the Wind'' exhibits, among them a 1994 exhibit titled, "Disputed Territories: ''Gone with the Wind'' and Southern Myths". One of the questions explored by the exhibit was "How True to Life Were the Slaves in GWTW?" This section showed slave experiences were diverse and concluded that the "happy darky" was a myth, as was the belief that all slaves experienced violence and brutality.<ref>{{cite book |last=Dickey |first=Jennifer W. |year=2014 |title=A Tough Little Patch of History: Gone with the Wind and the politics of memory |publisher=[[University of Arkansas Press]] |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=jdtXAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA66#v=onepage 66] |isbn= 978-1-55728-657-4}}</ref>
Despite factual inaccuracies in its depiction of the Reconstruction period, it nevertheless reflects contemporary interpretations common throughout the early 20th century. One pervasive viewpoint argued by academics is reflected in a brief scene in which Mammy fends off a leering [[freedman]]: a government official can be heard offering bribes to the emancipated slaves for their votes. The clear inference is that freedmen are ignorant about politics and unprepared for freedom, unwittingly becoming the tools of corrupt Reconstruction officials. While perpetuating some [[Lost Cause of the Confederacy|Lost Cause]] myths, the film makes concessions in regards to others. After the attack on Scarlett in the shanty town, a group of men including Scarlett's husband Frank, Rhett Butler and Ashley raid the town; in the novel they belong to the Ku Klux Klan, representing the common trope of protecting the white woman's virtue, but the filmmakers consciously neutralize the presence of the Klan in the film by referring to it only as a "political meeting".<ref name="Ruiz">{{cite book |first=W. Bryan Rommel |last=Ruiz |year=2010 |title=American History Goes to the Movies: Hollywood and the American Experience |publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] |isbn=978-0-203-83373-5 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=MEfE-WxwAJwC&pg=PA61 61]}}</ref>
Thomas Cripps has argued that the film in some respects undercuts racial stereotypes;<ref name="Smyth">{{cite book |first=J.E. |last=Smyth |year=2006 |title=Reconstructing American Historical Cinema: From Cimarron to Citizen Kane |publisher=[[University Press of Kentucky]] |isbn=978-0-8131-7147-0 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=R5_n4834AgYC&pg=PA164 164]}}</ref> in particular, the film created greater engagement between Hollywood and black audiences,<ref name="Smyth" /> with dozens of movies making small gestures in recognition of the emerging trend.<ref name="Lupack" /> Only a few weeks after its initial run, a story editor at Warner wrote a memo to [[Walter Wanger]] about ''Mississippi Belle'', a script that contained the worst excesses of plantation films, suggesting that ''Gone with the Wind'' had made the film "unproducible". More than any film since ''The Birth of a Nation'', it unleashed a variety of social forces that foreshadowed an alliance of white liberals and blacks who encouraged the expectation that blacks would one day achieve equality. According to Cripps, the film eventually became a template for measuring social change.<ref name="Lupack" />
===Depiction of marital rape=== One of the most notorious and widely condemned scenes in ''Gone with the Wind'' depicts what is now legally defined as "[[marital rape]]".<ref name="White">{{cite book |editor1-first=John |editor1-last=White |editor2-first=Sabine |editor2-last=Haenni |year=2009 |title=Fifty Key American Films |series=Routledge Key Guides|publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn=978-0-203-89113-1 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=u7gZRtn44AAC&pg=PA59 59]}}</ref><ref name="Hickok">{{cite book |first=Eugene W., Jr. |last=Hickok |year=1991 |title=The Bill of Rights: Original Meaning and Current Understanding |publisher=[[University of Virginia Press]] |isbn=978-0-8139-1336-0 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Eik_eoTn6KEC&pg=PA103 103]}}</ref> The scene begins with Scarlett and Rhett at the bottom of the staircase, where he begins to kiss her, refusing to be told 'no' by the struggling and frightened Scarlett;<ref name="Paludi">{{cite book |first=Michele A. |last=Paludi |year=2012 |title=The Psychology of Love |volume=2 |series=Women's Psychology |publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]] |isbn=978-0-313-39315-0 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=BtK9MKx8QBQC&pg=PR26 xxvi]}}</ref><ref name="Allison">{{cite book |first1=Julie A. |last1=Allison |first2=Lawrence S. |last2=Wrightsman |year=1993 |title=Rape: The Misunderstood Crime |edition=2 |publisher=[[Sage Publications]] |isbn=978-0-8039-3707-9 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=GI0BXXNQJ-QC&pg=PA90 90]}}</ref> Rhett overcomes her resistance and carries her up the stairs to the bedroom,<ref name="Paludi" /><ref name="Allison" /> where the audience is left in no doubt that she will "get what's coming to her".<ref name="Pagelow">{{cite book |first1=Mildred Daley |last1=Pagelow |first2=Lloyd W. |last2=Pagelow |year=1984 |title=Family Violence |series=Praeger special studies |publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]] |isbn=978-0-275-91623-7 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=VPPapvrJsTcC&pg=PA420 420]}}</ref> The next scene, the following morning, shows Scarlett glowing with barely suppressed sexual satisfaction;<ref name="Paludi" /><ref name="Allison" /><ref name="Pagelow" /> Rhett apologizes for his behavior, blaming it on his drinking.<ref name="Paludi" /> The scene has been accused of combining romance and rape by making them indistinguishable from each other,<ref name="Paludi" /> and of reinforcing a notion about [[forced seduction|forced sex]]: that women secretly enjoy it, and it is an acceptable way for a man to treat his wife.<ref name="Pagelow" />
[[Molly Haskell]] has argued that nevertheless, women are mostly uncritical of the scene, and that by and large it is consistent with what women have in mind when they [[Rape fantasy|fantasize about being raped]]. Their fantasies revolve around love and romance rather than forced sex; they assume that Scarlett was not an unwilling sexual partner and wanted Rhett to take the initiative and insist on having sexual intercourse.<ref name="Frus">{{cite book |first=Phyllis |last=Frus |editor-first=J. David |editor-last=Slocum |chapter=Documenting Domestic Violence in American Films |year=2001 |title=Violence in American Cinema |series=Afi Film Readers |publisher=[[Routledge]] |isbn=978-0-415-92810-6 |page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=3bIYD6uo3jQC&pg=RA1-PA231 231]}}</ref>

===Sequel=== Following publication of her novel, Margaret Mitchell was inundated with requests for a sequel but claimed to not have a notion of what happened to Scarlett and Rhett, and that she had "left them to their ultimate fate". Mitchell continued to resist pressure from Selznick and MGM to write a sequel until her death in 1949. In 1975, her brother, Stephens Mitchell (who assumed control of her estate), authorized a sequel to be jointly produced by MGM and [[Universal Studios]] on a budget of $12 million. [[Anne Edwards]] was commissioned to write the sequel as a novel which would then be adapted into a screenplay, and published in conjunction with the film's release. Edwards submitted a 775-page manuscript entitled ''Tara, The Continuation of Gone with the Wind'', set between 1872 and 1882 focusing on Scarlett's divorce from Rhett; MGM was not satisfied with the story and the deal collapsed.<ref name="Bartel" />
The idea was revived in the 1990s, when a sequel was finally produced in 1994, in the form of a television [[miniseries]]. ''[[Scarlett (TV miniseries)|Scarlett]]'' was based upon [[Scarlett (Ripley novel)|the novel]] by [[Alexandra Ripley]], itself a sequel to Mitchell's book. British actors [[Joanne Whalley]] and [[Timothy Dalton]] were cast as Scarlett and Rhett, and the series follows Scarlett's relocation to Ireland after again becoming pregnant by Rhett.<ref name="scarlett">{{cite web |title=Scarlett (1994) |work=[[Allmovie]] |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |url=http://www.allmovie.com/movie/scarlett-v135447 |accessdate=March 3, 2013}}</ref>
